text: Oh that men would praise the LORD for his goodness, and for his wonderful works to the children of men!
text_kjv: Oh that men would praise the LORD for his goodness, and for his wonderful works to the children of men!
text_niv: Let them give thanks to the Lord for his unfailing loveand his wonderful deeds for men.
text_esv: Let them thank the LORD for his steadfast love, for his wondrous works to the children of man!
text_nlt: Let them praise the LORD for his great loveand for the wonderful things he has done for them.
text_msg: So thank God for his marvelous love,for his miracle mercy to the children he loves;
text_nasb: Let them give thanks to the LORD for His lovingkindness, And for His wonders to the sons of men!
context: Psalm 107 is a psalm of thanksgiving, categorized as both a communal thanksgiving psalm and a wisdom psalm. Its composition is likely post-exilic, written after the Israelites returned from their Babylonian captivity (around 539 BC). This is strongly suggested by the recurring themes of redemption from exile and wandering in desolate places, reminiscent of their experiences. The structure follows a pattern: a description of distress (wandering, imprisonment, sickness, storms), a cry to the Lord, God's deliverance, and a refrain urging thanksgiving. The repeated call to praise highlights the central purpose: to encourage gratitude for God's steadfast love (Hesed) and His active intervention in the lives of His people. The phrase "children of men" is a common Hebrew idiom representing all humanity, emphasizing that God's goodness extends beyond the nation of Israel. The historical context of exile and return provided a powerful backdrop for these expressions of gratitude. The psalmist likely drew upon shared memories of hardship and divine rescue, fostering a collective sense of relief and renewed covenant commitment. The 'wonderful works' would have included tangible blessings like provision of food and water in the desert, safe passage home, and the restoration of their land. Understanding the trauma and subsequent joy of this period enriches our comprehension of the Psalmist's heartfelt plea for praise.
meaning: Psalm 107:21 underscores the theological importance of gratitude as a fitting response to God's character and actions. The verse isn't merely a suggestion; it's a heartfelt exhortation, expressing the Psalmist's deep longing that people recognize and acknowledge God's inherent goodness and His tangible interventions. 'Goodness' refers not just to an attribute but to God's benevolent nature, His inherent desire to bless and care for His creation. 'Wonderful works' encompass God's miraculous interventions, His acts of power and provision that defy natural explanations and demonstrate His sovereignty. The phrase "children of men" is significant because it expands the scope of God's goodness beyond a single nation. It implies a universal call to recognize God's favor and to express gratitude regardless of ethnicity or background. The theological implication is that all humanity is the recipient of God's grace, even though they may not acknowledge it. This verse highlights the interconnectedness between God's actions and humanity's response. God initiates His grace, and humanity is called to respond with praise. This response isn't just a matter of etiquette; it's a recognition of God's rightful place as Creator and Sustainer. Praising God acknowledges His attributes, declares His power, and expresses our dependence upon Him. It's an act of worship that aligns our hearts with God's purposes and draws us into a deeper relationship with Him. Failure to praise God implies a denial of His goodness and a rejection of His loving care.
application: Psalm 107:21 calls us to cultivate a lifestyle of gratitude in our modern lives. It challenges us to actively seek out and acknowledge God's goodness, even in the midst of hardship. This means going beyond simply saying "thank you" occasionally and instead developing a consistent habit of recognizing God's presence and provision in our daily experiences. We can start by keeping a gratitude journal, listing three to five things each day for which we are thankful. This practice helps us to focus on the positive aspects of our lives and to recognize God's hand at work. We can also express our gratitude through acts of service. When we see a need, we can respond with compassion and generosity, reflecting God's love to others. This could involve volunteering our time, donating to charitable causes, or simply offering a helping hand to someone in need. Another way to apply this verse is to be more intentional about expressing gratitude to others. A simple "thank you" can go a long way in brightening someone's day and fostering positive relationships. We can also write thank-you notes to people who have made a difference in our lives, expressing our appreciation for their kindness and support. Furthermore, in a world saturated with negativity and complaint, we can be deliberate about speaking words of praise and encouragement. This not only lifts up others but also shifts our own perspective and cultivates a more grateful heart. Finally, we can regularly reflect on the "wonderful works" God has done in our own lives and in the lives of others. This helps us to remember His faithfulness and to trust in His continued provision. Share stories of answered prayers or moments where you witnessed God's intervention in the world.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often take your goodness for granted. Forgive me for my moments of ingratitude and help me to cultivate a heart that overflows with thanksgiving. Open my eyes to see your 'wonderful works' in my life and in the world around me. Teach me to praise you not only in times of ease but also in times of difficulty. Help me to be a beacon of gratitude, reflecting your love and grace to all those I encounter. May my life be a testament to your goodness and a constant offering of praise. I long to express my thanks for your salvation through Jesus Christ and the hope of eternal life. Strengthen my faith, Lord, so I may praise you continually. Amen.

faqs.answer: The phrase 'children of men' emphasizes the universal scope of God's goodness and salvation. It highlights that God's love and care extend beyond the boundaries of a single nation, inviting all people to recognize and respond to His blessings.
faqs.question: Q1: Why does the verse specify 'children of men' rather than just 'Israel'?

faqs.answer: Praising God shifts our focus from our problems to His power. It cultivates contentment, reduces anxiety, strengthens our faith, and deepens our relationship with Him, reminding us of His consistent presence.
faqs.question: Q2: How does praising God benefit us personally?

faqs.answer: 'Wonderful works' can include answered prayers, healing from illness, provision in times of need, reconciliation in broken relationships, and moments of unexpected grace or divine intervention that defy explanation.
faqs.question: Q3: What are some concrete examples of 'wonderful works' God does today?

faqs.answer: Even in hardship, we can praise God by focusing on His unchanging character, His past faithfulness, and the hope of eternal life. Praising Him in adversity is an act of trust and surrender.
faqs.question: Q4: How can we praise God when we are facing difficult circumstances?

faqs.answer: Thanksgiving expresses gratitude for specific blessings, while praise focuses on God's attributes and worthiness, regardless of circumstances. Both are vital aspects of a healthy relationship with God.
faqs.question: Q5: Is there a difference between thanksgiving and praise?
